Explanations about Options.-e(M):
Execute the statement and quit. The default output format is like that produced with
 --batch. See Section 4.2.2.1, “Using Options on the Command Line”, for some examples.
 With this option, mysql does not use the history file.
Explanations about Options.-q(M):
Do not cache each query result, print each row as it is received. This may slow down
 the server if the output is suspended. With this option, mysql does not use the
 history file.
Explanations about Options.-s(M):
Silent mode. Produce less output. This option can be given multiple times to produce
 less and less output.
 This option results in nontabular output format and escaping of special characters.
 Escaping may be disabled by using raw mode; see the description for the --raw option.
Explanations about Options.-u(M): The user name of the MySQL account to use for connecting to the server.

Answers.Most Similar TLDR Task: Execute SQL statements in a script file (batch file)

-u : Specify mysql database user name
-p : Prompt for password
-e : Execute sql query
database : Specify database name

sudo mysql -u username -p'PassWord' -e 'SELECT COUNT(*) FROM my_table'

mysql -u root -ppass myDB -e "select * from table limit 10;" >> /root/test.log

Explanations about Options.--databases(C): You can dump different databases with: mysqldump [options] --databases DB1 [DB2 DB3...].
Explanations about Options.--databases(M):
Dump several databases. Normally, mysqldump treats the first name argument on the
 command line as a database name and following names as table names. With this option,
 it treats all name arguments as database names. CREATE DATABASE and USE statements
 are included in the output before each new database.
 This option may be used to dump the performance_schema database, which normally is not
 dumped even with the --all-databases option. (Also use the --skip-lock-tables option.)
Explanations about Options.--user(M): The user name of the MySQL account to use for connecting to the server.
Explanations about Options.-u(M): The user name of the MySQL account to use for connecting to the server.
